binge eating disorder

For many patients, binge eating disorder is a cycle of…

Binge, shame, guilt.
Repeat.

Adults with binge eating disorder (BED) carry on in silence for years, too embarrassed and ashamed to talk about their bingeing, all the while compromising their physical and mental health. 1-8

It’s time to interrupt their suffering.

BED is the most common eating disorder
It often goes untreated for years
BED is a psychological condition
Emerging evidence of BED neurobiology
Finding BED in your patients

Recognizing BED

The DSM-5 defines BED as recurring episodes (at least once per week for 3 months) of eating a large amount of food in a short period of time, with episodes characterized by feelings of lack of control and marked distress regarding binge eating.1

BED is different from bulimia nervosa

It is not associated with compensatory behaviors such as purging or excessive exercise, or with dietary restriction, although frequent dieting may be reported.1

BED is different from overeating

While overeating is a challenge for many Americans, recurrent binge eating is much less common, far more severe, and is associated with significant physical and psychological problems.23

BED is different from obesity

Adults with BED are more likely than weight-matched obese adults without BED to1:

  • Overestimate the importance of body weight and shape
  • Have other psychiatric conditions
  • Experience functional impairment
  • Have lower quality of life

BED occurs in normal-weight, overweight, and obese individuals2

The DSM-5® criteria

Essential features of binge eating disorder

In order to be diagnosed with BED, an individual must meet all of the following DSM-5 diagnostic criteria:

Diagnostic criteria1:

  1. Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of binge eating is characterized by both of the following:
    1. Eating, in a discrete period of time (e.g., within any 2-hour period), an amount of food that is definitely larger than what most people would eat in a similar period of time under similar circumstances.
    2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the episode (e.g., a feeling that one cannot stop eating or control what or how much one is eating).
  2. The binge-eating episodes are associated with three (or more) of the following:
    1. Eating much more rapidly than normal.
    2. Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.
    3. Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.
    4. Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.
    5. Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.
  3. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present.
  4. Episodes occur, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.
  5. Not associated with inappropriate compensatory behavior such as purging or excessive exercise.

Diagnosis should be based upon a complete evaluation of the patient.

DSM-5® Criteria

What is a large amount of food?

The amount of food may not be particularly meaningful when considering binge eating:

  • Typical binges are often in the range of 2,000 to 5,000 calories24
  • But whether any binge is objectively or subjectively defined as “large” may not matter because in either case the individual feels a loss of control and marked distress25
What is a large amount of food?
BED Resources

Resources

Now that you have a better understanding of BED, this information may help you to identify and accurately diagnose adults with BED in your practice.

Starting the conversation

These questions may help you begin a dialogue with your adult patients about their eating behavior and feelings toward food.

General screening1

  • Do you worry that you have lost control over how much you eat?
  • Would you say that food dominates your life?

Specific for BED diagnosis1

  • Do you often eat within any 2-hour period what most people would regard as an unusual amount of food?
  • During these binges did you eat…
    • Much more rapidly than normal?
    • Until you felt uncomfortably full?
    • Large amounts of food when you didn’t feel physically hungry?
    • Alone because you were embarrassed by how much you were eating?
  • Was it very upsetting to you that you couldn’t stop eating or control what or how much you were eating?
  • How often did you binge?

If you or your adult patients would like more information about BED, these organizations may be able to help:

    www.ama-assn.org/ama

    (800) 374-2721
